Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Fully Closed-Loop Versus Usual Care Glucose Control in Major Abdominal Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: Thirty-eight patients aged ≥18 years undergoing major abdominal surgery were randomised (1:1) to FCL or UC glucose management.

Participants.evidence: Thirty-eight patients aged ≥18 years undergoing major abdominal surgery were randomised (1:1) to FCL or UC glucose management.

Intervention.evidence: randomised (1:1) to FCL or UC glucose management.

Objective.evidence: This study assesses the efficacy and safety of fully closed-loop (FCL) glucose control compared to usual care (UC).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the proportion of time with sensor glucose values in the target range of 5.6 to 10.0 mmol/L from hospital admission to discharge (max 20 days).

Blinding.evidence: open-label with masked continuous glucose monitoring in the UC group.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Thirty-eight patients aged ≥18 years undergoing major abdominal surgery were randomised (1:1)

Number_Analysed.evidence: Thirty-seven patients were analysed (18 FCL, 19 UC) using a modified intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The FCL group spent 80.1% ± 10.0% of time in the target range compared to 53.7% ± 19.7% in the UC group (P < 0.001).

Harms.evidence: No study-related serious adverse events occurred, with four serious adverse events in the FCL group unrelated to the study.
